The **appendix** (or **vermiform appendix** ; also **cecal** [or **caecal**]
**appendix** ; **vermix** ; or **vermiform process**) is a blind-ended tube
connected to the [cecum](/wiki/Cecum "Cecum"), from which it [develops in the
embryo](/wiki/Prenatal_development "Prenatal development"). The cecum is a
pouchlike structure of the [colon](/wiki/Large_intestine#Structure "Large
intestine"), located at the junction of the [small](/wiki/Small_intestine
"Small intestine") and the [large intestines](/wiki/Large_intestine "Large
intestine").

The term "[vermiform](/wiki/Vermiform "Vermiform")" comes from
[Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") and means "worm-shaped".

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

The human appendix averages 9 cm in length but can range from 2 to 20 cm. The
diameter of the appendix is usually between 7 and 8 mm. The longest appendix
ever removed was 26 cm long. It was removed from a patient in
[Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb "Zagreb"), [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia").[1] The
appendix is usually located in the lower right
[quadrant](/wiki/Quadrant_\(anatomy\) "Quadrant \(anatomy\)") of the
[abdomen](/wiki/Abdomen "Abdomen"), near the right [hip
bone](/wiki/Iliac_fossa "Iliac fossa"). The base of the appendix is located 2
cm beneath the [ileocecal valve](/wiki/Ileocecal_valve "Ileocecal valve") that
separates the large intestine from the small intestine. Its position within
the abdomen corresponds to a point on the surface known as [McBurney's
point](/wiki/McBurney%27s_point "McBurney's point").

The appendix is connected to the [mesentery](/wiki/Mesentery "Mesentery") in
the lower region of the [ileum](/wiki/Ileum "Ileum"), by a short region of the
[mesocolon](/wiki/Mesentery "Mesentery") known as the
[mesoappendix](/wiki/Mesentery#Segments "Mesentery").[2]

###
Variation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Variation")]

Some identical twins—known as [mirror image
twins](/wiki/Twin#Mirror_image_twins "Twin")—can have a [mirror-imaged
anatomy](/wiki/Situs_inversus "Situs inversus"), a [congenital
condition](/wiki/Congenital_disorder "Congenital disorder") with the appendix
located in the lower left quadrant of the abdomen.[3][4][5] [Intestinal
malrotation](/wiki/Intestinal_malrotation "Intestinal malrotation") may also
cause displacement of the appendix to the left side.

While the base of the appendix is at a fairly constant location—2 cm below the
[ileocecal valve](/wiki/Ileocecal_valve "Ileocecal valve"), the tip of the
appendix can be variably located—in the [pelvis](/wiki/Pelvis "Pelvis"),
outside the [peritoneum](/wiki/Peritoneum "Peritoneum") or behind the
cecum.[6] The prevalence of the different positions varies amongst populations
with the retrocecal position being most common in [Ghana](/wiki/Ghana "Ghana")
and [Sudan](/wiki/Sudan "Sudan"), with 67.3% and 58.3% occurrence
respectively, in comparison to [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") and
[Bosnia](/wiki/Bosnia "Bosnia") where the pelvic position is most common, with
55.8% and 57.7% occurrence respectively.[7][8][9][10]

In very rare cases ([laparotomies](/wiki/Laparotomy "Laparotomy") for
suspected appendicitis have given a frequency of 1 in 100,000), the appendix
may not be present at all.[11]

Sometimes there is a semi-circular fold of [mucous
membrane](/wiki/Mucous_membrane "Mucous membrane") at the opening of the
appendix. This _valve of the vermiform appendix_ is also called [Gerlach's
valve](/wiki/Joseph_von_Gerlach "Joseph von Gerlach").[2]

##
Functions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Functions")]

### Maintaining gut
flora[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Maintaining gut flora")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Appendix_function_diagram.svg/220px-
Appendix_function_diagram.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Appendix_function_diagram.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Appendix_function_diagram.svg "Enlarge")

A possible function of the human appendix is a "safe house" for beneficial
bacteria in the recovery from [diarrhea](/wiki/Diarrhea "Diarrhea").

Although it has been long accepted that the immune tissue surrounding the
appendix and elsewhere in the gut—called [gut associated lymphoid
tissue](/wiki/Gut_associated_lymphoid_tissue "Gut associated lymphoid
tissue")—carries out a number of important functions, explanations were
lacking for the distinctive shape of the appendix and its apparent lack of
specific importance and function as judged by an absence of side effects
following [its removal](/wiki/Appendectomy "Appendectomy").[12] Therefore, the
notion that the appendix is only [vestigial](/wiki/Vestigiality
"Vestigiality") became widely held.

William Parker, Randy Bollinger, and colleagues at [Duke
University](/wiki/Duke_University "Duke University") proposed in 2007 that the
appendix serves as a haven for useful [bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria "Bacteria")
when illness flushes those bacteria from the rest of the intestines.[13][14]
This proposal is based on an understanding that emerged by the early 2000s of
how the immune system supports the growth of beneficial [intestinal
bacteria](/wiki/Gut_flora "Gut flora"),[15][16] in combination with many well-
known features of the appendix, including its architecture, its location just
below the normal one-way flow of food and germs in the large intestine, and
its association with copious amounts of immune tissue. Research performed at
[Winthrop–University Hospital](/wiki/Winthrop%E2%80%93University_Hospital
"Winthrop–University Hospital") showed that individuals without an appendix
were four times more likely to have a recurrence of _[Clostridium difficile
colitis](/wiki/Clostridium_difficile_colitis "Clostridium difficile
colitis")_.[17] The appendix, therefore, may act as a safe house for good
bacteria.[13] This reservoir of bacteria could then serve to repopulate the
[gut flora](/wiki/Gut_flora "Gut flora") in the [digestive
system](/wiki/Human_digestive_system "Human digestive system") following a
bout of [dysentery](/wiki/Dysentery "Dysentery") or [cholera](/wiki/Cholera
"Cholera"), or boost it following a milder gastrointestinal illness.[14]

### Immune and lymphatic
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Immune and lymphatic system")]

The appendix has been identified as an important component of mammalian
[mucosal immune function](/wiki/Mucosal_immunology "Mucosal immunology"),
particularly [B cell](/wiki/B_cell "B cell") mediated immune responses and
[extrathymically](/wiki/Thymus "Thymus") derived [T cells](/wiki/T_cell "T
cell"). This structure helps in the proper movement and removal of waste
matter in the digestive system, contains lymphatic vessels that regulate
pathogens, and lastly, might even produce early defences that prevent deadly
diseases. Additionally, it is thought that this may provide more immune
defences from invading pathogens and getting the lymphatic system's B and T
cells to fight the viruses and bacteria that infect that portion of the bowel
and training them, so that immune responses are targeted and more able to
reliably and less dangerously fight off pathogens.[18] In addition there are
different immune cells called [innate lymphoid
cells](/wiki/Innate_lymphoid_cell "Innate lymphoid cell") that function in the
gut, to help the appendix maintain digestive health.[19][20]

###
Vestigiality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Vestigiality")]

The human appendix had been proposed to be a [vestigial
structure](/wiki/Human_vestigiality "Human vestigiality"), a structure that
has lost all or most of its original function, or that has evolved to take on
a new function. The suggestion was that it is the shrunken remnant of the
[cecum](/wiki/Cecum "Cecum") thought to have been present in a remote ancestor
of humans. This notion is still widely held. A 2013 study, however, refutes
the idea of an inverse relationship between cecum size and appendix size and
presence.[21] Ceca, which occur in the digestive tracts of many herbivores
(e.g. ox, horse), house mutualistic bacteria and ingested small stones that
help animals digest the cellulose molecules found in plants.[22]

It is widely present in [euarchontoglires](/wiki/Euarchontoglires
"Euarchontoglires") (a superorder of mammals that includes rodents and
primates) and has also evolved [independently](/wiki/Convergent_evolution
"Convergent evolution") in the [diprotodont](/wiki/Diprotodont "Diprotodont")
[marsupials](/wiki/Marsupials "Marsupials"), [monotremes](/wiki/Monotremes
"Monotremes"), and is highly diverse in size and shape.[21][23]

A possible scenario for the progression from a fully functional cecum to the
current human appendix was put forth by [Charles Darwin](/wiki/Charles_Darwin
"Charles Darwin"). He suggested that the appendix was used for digesting
leaves as [primates](/wiki/Primate "Primate"). It may be a vestigial organ of
ancient humans that has degraded to nearly nothing of its original purpose, or
evolved to take on a new purpose over the course of evolution. The very long
cecum of some herbivorous animals, such as found in the [horse](/wiki/Horse
"Horse") or the [koala](/wiki/Koala "Koala"), appears to support this theory.
The koala's cecum enables it to host bacteria that specifically help to break
down cellulose. Human ancestors may have also relied upon this system when
they lived on a diet rich in foliage. As people began to eat more easily
digested foods, they may have become less reliant on cellulose-rich plants for
energy. As the cecum became less necessary for digestion, mutations that were
previously deleterious (and would have hindered evolutionary progress) were no
longer important, so the mutations survived. It is suggested that these
[alleles](/wiki/Allele "Allele") became more frequent and the cecum continued
to shrink. After millions of years, the once-necessary cecum degraded to be
the appendix of modern humans.[24]

## Clinical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Appendiceal_carcinoid_1.JPG/220px-
Appendiceal_carcinoid_1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Appendiceal_carcinoid_1.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Appendiceal_carcinoid_1.JPG "Enlarge")

An appendiceal carcinoid tumor

The most common [diseases](/wiki/Disease "Disease") of the appendix (in
humans) are [appendicitis](/wiki/Appendicitis "Appendicitis") and
[carcinoid](/wiki/Carcinoid "Carcinoid") tumors (appendiceal carcinoid).[25]
[Appendix cancer](/wiki/Appendix_cancer "Appendix cancer") accounts for about
1 in 200 of all gastrointestinal malignancies. In rare cases,
[adenomas](/wiki/Adenomas "Adenomas") are also present.[26]

###
Appendicitis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Appendicitis")]

Main article: [Appendicitis](/wiki/Appendicitis "Appendicitis")

[Appendicitis](/wiki/Appendicitis "Appendicitis") is a condition characterized
by [inflammation](/wiki/Inflammation "Inflammation") of the appendix. Pain
often begins in the center of the abdomen, corresponding to the appendix's
development as part of the embryonic [midgut](/wiki/Midgut "Midgut"). This
pain is typically a dull, poorly localized, [visceral](/wiki/Viscus "Viscus")
pain.[27]

As the inflammation progresses, the pain begins to localize more clearly to
the right lower quadrant, as the [peritoneum](/wiki/Peritoneum "Peritoneum")
becomes inflamed. This peritoneal inflammation, or
[peritonitis](/wiki/Peritonitis "Peritonitis"), results in [rebound
tenderness](/wiki/Rebound_tenderness "Rebound tenderness") (pain upon removal
of pressure rather than application of pressure). In particular, it presents
at [McBurney's point](/wiki/McBurney%27s_point "McBurney's point"), 1/3 of the
way along a line drawn from the [anterior superior iliac
spine](/wiki/Anterior_superior_iliac_spine "Anterior superior iliac spine") to
the [umbilicus](/wiki/Navel "Navel"). Typically, point (skin) pain is not
present until the [parietal peritoneum](/wiki/Parietal_peritoneum "Parietal
peritoneum") is inflamed, as well. Fever and an immune system response are
also characteristic of appendicitis.[27]

Appendicitis usually requires the removal of the inflamed appendix, in an
[appendectomy](/wiki/Appendectomy "Appendectomy") either by
[laparotomy](/wiki/Laparotomy "Laparotomy") or [laparoscopy](/wiki/Laparoscopy
"Laparoscopy"). Untreated, the appendix may rupture, leading to
[peritonitis](/wiki/Peritonitis "Peritonitis"), followed by shock, and, if
still untreated, death.[27]

###
Surgery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Surgery")]

Main article: [Appendectomy](/wiki/Appendectomy "Appendectomy")

The surgical removal of the appendix is called an
[appendectomy](/wiki/Appendectomy "Appendectomy"). This removal is normally
performed as an emergency procedure when the patient is suffering from
[acute](/wiki/Acute_\(medical\) "Acute \(medical\)") appendicitis. In the
absence of surgical facilities, [intravenous](/wiki/Intravenous "Intravenous")
[antibiotics](/wiki/Antibiotics "Antibiotics") are used to delay or avoid the
onset of [sepsis](/wiki/Sepsis "Sepsis"). In some cases, the appendicitis
resolves completely; more often, an inflammatory mass forms around the
appendix. This is a relative [contraindication](/wiki/Contraindication
"Contraindication") to surgery.

The appendix is also used for the construction of an efferent urinary conduit,
in an operation known as the [Mitrofanoff
procedure](/wiki/Mitrofanoff_procedure "Mitrofanoff procedure"),[28] in people
with a [neurogenic bladder](/wiki/Neurogenic_bladder "Neurogenic bladder").

The appendix is also used as a means to access the colon in children with
paralysed bowels or major rectal sphincter problems. The appendix is brought
out to the skin surface and the child/parent can then attach a catheter and
easily wash out the colon (via normal defaecation) using an appropriate
solution.[29]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Appendix_\(anatomy\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: History")]

Dr. Heather F. Smith of [Midwestern University](/wiki/Midwestern_University
"Midwestern University") and colleagues explained:

> Recently ... improved understanding of gut immunity has merged with current
> thinking in biological and medical science, pointing to an apparent function
> of the mammalian cecal appendix as a safe-house for symbiotic gut microbes,
> preserving the flora during times of gastrointestinal infection in societies
> without modern medicine. This function is potentially a selective force for
> the evolution and maintenance of the appendix. Three morphotypes of cecal-
> appendices can be described among mammals based primarily on the shape of
> the cecum: a distinct appendix branching from a rounded or sac-like cecum
> (as in many primate species), an appendix located at the apex of a long and
> voluminous cecum (as in the rabbit, greater glider and Cape dune mole rat),
> and an appendix in the absence of a pronounced cecum (as in the wombat). In
> addition, long narrow appendix-like structures are found in mammals that
> either lack an apparent cecum (as in monotremes) or lack a distinct junction
> between the cecum and appendix-like structure (as in the koala). A cecal
> appendix has evolved independently at least twice, and apparently represents
> yet another example of convergence in morphology between Australian
> marsupials and placentals in the rest of the world. Although the appendix
> has apparently been lost by numerous species, it has also been maintained
> for more than 80 million years in at least one clade.[23]

In a more recent paper, the appendix was found to have evolved at least 32
times (and perhaps as many as 38 times) and to have been lost no more than six
times.[21] This suggests that the cecal appendix has a selective advantage in
many situations and argues strongly against its vestigial nature. This complex
evolutionary history of the appendix, along with a great heterogeneity in its
evolutionary rate in various taxa, suggests that it is a recurrent trait.[30]

Such a function may be useful in a culture lacking modern sanitation and
healthcare practice, where [diarrhea](/wiki/Diarrhea "Diarrhea") may be
prevalent. Current [epidemiological](/wiki/Epidemiology "Epidemiology") data
on the cause of death in developed countries collected by the [World Health
Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") in
2001 show that acute diarrhea is now the fourth leading cause of disease-
related death in developing countries (data summarized by The [Bill and
Melinda Gates Foundation](/wiki/Bill_and_Melinda_Gates_Foundation "Bill and
Melinda Gates Foundation")). Two of the other leading causes of death are
expected to have exerted limited or no selection pressure.[31][32]
